John Quincy ADAMS from his first entrance In
to political life, commanded the respect, ami excl
ted the attention of all parties, by the display OF
abilities which only found IN the ablest states
man. Not "a few, at an early day, saw the germs OF
talents which ould IN time elevate him to the high
est Office in his country's gift. Hear WAsHlNeToN,
JEFFERSON. MADISON, and MONROE, speak OF his
qualifications What higher authorities could we
ask9


WASHINGTON, speaking of Mr.. ADAMS in his ear
| ly DAYS, when Minister to foreign Court. de-
cared it as his opinion that he would become one OF
our most vatuabie public characters. JEFFERSON
spake of him as an able, honest, and learned man,
and one who would make a sale Chief Magistrate tor
the Union. MADISON had high opinion OF his d-
plonatic skill, and in this line believed he had NO
superior. MONROE praised him an able assistant
in his administration, and said whatever success 1t
had obtained from the People, was greatly to be at
tributed to Mr. ApAMs's counsels.


Not only did these men speak in this manner OF
MIR. ADAMS, but he enjoyed their confidence, and
was employed in distngul shed public capacity by
each. Now call JACKSON forth, and where will you


find four men like these who will impartlay give tes
timony of his possessing qualifications that would
adorn the Presidential chairf Search through the
four and twenty States, and such testimony can nt
where be discovered.


Hear General Jackson speak, in 1917, of the
qualifications of Mr.. ADAMS, to Mr.. Monroe, Whel
lie was appointed by the latter Secretary OF State
I'.You have made (,ays the General,) the BES
|CHOlCE THAT COULD BE MADE. In tn
hour Of difficulty he will be found an able helpnmt
|and am convinced his appointment will give gen
era satisfaction Who, reading the abnve test
monies, can doubt Mr.. ApAMs's qualifications t
ably fill the Presidential chair? Certainly no on
unbnded with the spirit of party

Mr. Eo1aet.-It was our melancholy duty to an
nounce yesterday that Mr. Emmett, while engaged
in his professional duties in TIL Circuit Court, was
struck with apoplexy; and the torebodngs which
were uttered as to the result realized. for he is
no more; he expired last night about half past ten
o'clock. The high standing of this gentleman, at
the bar his talents and character. the circumstances
of this le-and those ofhs death, combine to take
him out Of the ordinary routine, aud require some
thing more at the hand ofpubc journalist than the
brief notice which daily records in his columns that
man is mortal.


OF the early life and history of Mr.. Emmet before
he came to the United States, il is not our purpose
to speak neither is it for as to aude to any acts OF
| his political career after he came here. Beneath
the pail which now enshrouds his cold remains, we
will see only the man of genius, the eloquent advo-
cate, the enlightened and polished gentleman, the
devoted and affectionate father, husband friend
sna,ched TOO soon, and in the ful!ness of his fame
and usefulness from the community that he adorn-
ed and served-from family that he dearly iov-
ed.


From the first moment Of Mr.. Emmet's admission
lin the bar of New York. he took leading place.
70 great fervour of mind and OF Manner united
with ready and emphatic eucution, MIR. Emmet
added the advantages of fine education, OF varied
and extensive literary requirements, and OF the
most untiring industry and perseverance. lie was
to the day of his death an eminent example OF a
conscientious and ndeIatigable counsellor, who


thinks nothing is done or his client, while any thina
From the New- York american, Nov Is.

We learn, by the Steamboat North America,
which arrived last evening from Albany, that the
recent cold weather has closed the navigation on the
Northern and Erie Canals. On Saturday night, ice
an inch and half in thickness formed in the basin
at Albany.


Snelson, who robbed the Bank of Virginia. ASSUME
ed the name Of Maxwell, on his arrival in Canada.
He sailed from Quebec in the Mary Cumming for
Liverpool. We learn from the Montreal Gazetles
tha, during his stay in that place. exchanged eIgh-
teen hundred dollars of the bills at the counting
house of Messrs Horatio Gates Il 90. Ga his
passage in the Chanby to Quebec. he made repea-
ted inquiries concerning the value of American bills.
tine means of conveyance to the West Indies, and
other questions which left no doubt of his being
auilty person. The notice Of the robbery had not
then arrived in Canada.

FOR this other, perhaps AS Uncommon, ana cefta'hy

OF his eoquence al the bar. we should say tervor

The circumstances of this distinguished mans
DEATH are in themselves singuarly affecting He
had been constantly and most arduousiy employed

was sent for, and every application which sh''i

gest was soon made, but made in vain. The blood
indeed flowed from the arm and the temples but
sense consciousness and intelligence had fled forever
The scene presented in the Court room, as this sad
truth became apparent, must have been heart rem
ding. The oldest members of the bar were IN tears
and sobbing aloud around their fallen and late m'sh-
ty compeer: the family of the lying man were coi-
lecting about him in all the agonies of hope. strug-
Cling against tespair--while he, whose voice had
50 lately filled that hall--mhose immortal mind had


held in breathless suspense the feelings of admirng
crowds lay bleeding, sPeechless, and unconscious


before them. He was removed in a litter about


O'Clock, to his own house, where he died. Yet,


is there in the manner of this death something gior-
Gus and consoatory. II recalls the great Chatham,
struck down among his peers OF the warrior PERISH
ing upon the field of his fame. The sprlt--the in-
mortal mind--h;s worn out its teebler and more
D worthless tenement-and returned to the God VINO
: gave it-unbroken by decay-and who can lament


such an issue to such life? Better, oh thousand


times better is it for such

Ofthe domestic virtues and affections of the de
ceased, it becomes not newspaper to speak--they
are too sacred for the public eye. The bleeding
hearts of those he has left behind him. are the most
affecting witnesses Of how much and how justly he
was beloved-how deeply, how endurinsly he VIII
be lamented.

TO THE EDITORS OF TAE NATIONAL IETELLIGENCER.


Geniiemea: Having reported to the Secretary OF
War, some months since that the original Plocee-
dngs of the General Court Martial, which conven-
ed ut Mobile the 5lh of December 1914, could not
be found on the flies of the Offices and subsequently,

received from d. Green. Esq. of this city, which
statement has been published in a newspaper; |
have now to request tie publication of an official let
ter on the same subject, and which is addressed to
the Secretary Of War.


Very respectfully, Il. JONES.

full articles.headline: From the New- York american, Nov Is.
full articles.article:
Mr. Eo1aet.-It was our melancholy duty to an
nounce yesterday that Mr. Emmett, while engaged
in his professional duties in TIL Circuit Court, was
struck with apoplexy; and the torebodngs which
were uttered as to the result realized. for he is
no more; he expired last night about half past ten
o'clock. The high standing of this gentleman, at
the bar his talents and character. the circumstances
of this le-and those ofhs death, combine to take
him out Of the ordinary routine, aud require some
thing more at the hand ofpubc journalist than the
brief notice which daily records in his columns that
man is mortal.


OF the early life and history of Mr.. Emmet before
he came to the United States, il is not our purpose
to speak neither is it for as to aude to any acts OF
| his political career after he came here. Beneath
the pail which now enshrouds his cold remains, we
will see only the man of genius, the eloquent advo-
cate, the enlightened and polished gentleman, the
devoted and affectionate father, husband friend
sna,ched TOO soon, and in the ful!ness of his fame
and usefulness from the community that he adorn-
ed and served-from family that he dearly iov-
ed.


From the first moment Of Mr.. Emmet's admission
lin the bar of New York. he took leading place.
70 great fervour of mind and OF Manner united
with ready and emphatic eucution, MIR. Emmet
added the advantages of fine education, OF varied
and extensive literary requirements, and OF the
most untiring industry and perseverance. lie was
to the day of his death an eminent example OF a
conscientious and ndeIatigable counsellor, who


thinks nothing is done or his client, while any thina

full articles.headline: From the Commercial Advertiser
full articles.article:
We learn, by the Steamboat North America,
which arrived last evening from Albany, that the
recent cold weather has closed the navigation on the
Northern and Erie Canals. On Saturday night, ice
an inch and half in thickness formed in the basin
at Albany.


Snelson, who robbed the Bank of Virginia. ASSUME
ed the name Of Maxwell, on his arrival in Canada.
He sailed from Quebec in the Mary Cumming for
Liverpool. We learn from the Montreal Gazetles
tha, during his stay in that place. exchanged eIgh-
teen hundred dollars of the bills at the counting
house of Messrs Horatio Gates Il 90. Ga his
passage in the Chanby to Quebec. he made repea-
ted inquiries concerning the value of American bills.
tine means of conveyance to the West Indies, and
other questions which left no doubt of his being
auilty person. The notice Of the robbery had not
then arrived in Canada.

THE LETTER AGAIN.
full articles.article:
No way abashed by the rebnifs the "kennel pres
ses" have hitherto received upon the subject of the
much talked of eterof Mr.. Webstel's, which no
body has ever seen. the Hon. Samuel C. Allen, of
Massachusetts. has been recently summoned before
the public. to sustain the charge. 1t will be seen.
however, by what follows, that this new attack has
been no less promptly met and put down by Mr.
Allen, than have been the former ones. The Green
field Mass Herald received this morning, contains
the following letter from Mr. A.
An article in a late number of the u. s. Tee-
graph, has been shewn mt, containing the following
paragraph


- We aver upon good authority. thai Mr.. Webster


did say, that he had letter in his possession which
lpledged Mr.. Adams to the Federal party, and he


did shew it to some aud offered to shew it to another


Federal gentleman as an inducement to influence
their votes for Mr.. Adams. We will now name Mr..


WarfieId. of Maryland Mr.. Allen of Massachusetts,


and Mr.. Nc Lane, of Delaware
The reference 10 my name in the above article
is wholly gratuous, and without the slightest au.
: thority from me, and so far as know, the state
i nent it contains is without the least foundation il


Ifact | never saw any letter from Mr.. Adams in the
possession of Mr.. Webster, or of any other person


relating to the Presidential election, or to the Fede
Il raj party, or any other party. never heard Mr.
e Webster say or intimate that he had such letter
n any letter from Mr.. Adams, nor ever have | ha
C any knowledge from any source, Of such letter.
SAMUEL G. ALLEN.
= Greenfield, Nor 7. 1897.


* 1t now remains for Mr.. Warfeld and Mr.. Milan
" TO come forth under their own proper names, IN
rs sustain the Telegraph and Richmond Enquirer,
is they can.

remains TO be done. tie was, inuecu. AhTuiy H'o'o
remarkable for his eloquence, real as that was, than
FOR this other, perhaps AS Uncommon, ana cefta'hy
as useful. characteristic.


OF his eoquence al the bar. we should say tervor
was the most striking quaty-a ervor not less OF
matter than of manner. He was eloquent, because
he was full the overl.wns Of breathing thoughts
suggested burning words. He was copioas, from a
Just reliance upon his accumulated stores otteraue,
which afforded the utmost variety of illustration and
argument I: and he was confident though EN- nentiy
courteous, in his manner and tone because he al
ways understood his cause, and entered upon it With
the zeal vt conviction.


The circumstances of this distinguished mans
DEATH are in themselves singuarly affecting He
had been constantly and most arduousiy employed
for some weeks in OF the greatest mporlah %
He had prepared hlmselfin them with his usual la
bour and research and as lately as Monday iasi' ne
made in the Astor speech, which, perhaps,
no one of his earlier efforts surpassed Without
allowing hsefa any espte, after this effort, he iorts
with, though verging, we presume, uponseVesi
ty years, entered upon the important contested c'hi
of the Sailors Snug Harbour. In attendance ulon
this cause, yesterday, that the hand OF DEAN
was laid upon him. In full Court, il was suddeny y
perceived that Mr. Emmett, had dropped upon the
table, The attorney General who was sitting nenT,
addressed him. but finding him. speech ass, the az m
was immediately communicated to the Conrt-wh
thereupon was forthwith adJourned--medicai aid
was sent for, and every application which sh''i
prompted by strong personal attachment, could sus1
gest was soon made, but made in vain. The blood
indeed flowed from the arm and the temples but
sense consciousness and intelligence had fled forever
The scene presented in the Court room, as this sad
truth became apparent, must have been heart rem
ding. The oldest members of the bar were IN tears
and sobbing aloud around their fallen and late m'sh-
ty compeer: the family of the lying man were coi-
lecting about him in all the agonies of hope. strug-
Cling against tespair--while he, whose voice had
50 lately filled that hall--mhose immortal mind had


held in breathless suspense the feelings of admirng
crowds lay bleeding, sPeechless, and unconscious


before them. He was removed in a litter about


O'Clock, to his own house, where he died. Yet,


is there in the manner of this death something gior-
Gus and consoatory. II recalls the great Chatham,
struck down among his peers OF the warrior PERISH
ing upon the field of his fame. The sprlt--the in-
mortal mind--h;s worn out its teebler and more
D worthless tenement-and returned to the God VINO
: gave it-unbroken by decay-and who can lament


such an issue to such life? Better, oh thousand


times better is it for such

full articles.article:
Ofthe domestic virtues and affections of the de
ceased, it becomes not newspaper to speak--they
are too sacred for the public eye. The bleeding
hearts of those he has left behind him. are the most
affecting witnesses Of how much and how justly he
was beloved-how deeply, how endurinsly he VIII
be lamented.


it is mentioned us striking circumstance. that the
day of Mr.. Enmet's death was the Oath anniv' Esa-
ry of that upon which he had filed the declaration OF
lis intention to become american citizen.

full articles.headline: DISPUTED BOUNDARY.
full articles.article:
Maine and Ne,v Brmsaoick. .-CharlesS S. Davies,
E,,, of Portland has been appointed by the Execu-
uve of MaiDe Agent, with authority to act IN De.
half Of the State, in obtaining information as to all
objects relating to the ghts Of property and juris-
dicton between the governments OF the State and
The Province of New Brunswick; and further to
inquire into the nature of the aggressions by nhabl-
,snts of sald Province of which complaints have re-
Gently been made to the Executive, by citizens OF
that State residing near the frontier.


In the mean time the Governor OF Maine has issued
the following


rRoCLAMATIoN.


Whereas it has been made known to the State that
one Of it, citizens has been conveyed from II, BY
Foreign Power to gaol in the Province oi New
Brunswick and that many trespasses have been
committed by inhabitants ol the same Province Oh
the sovereignty of Maine and the rights OF those she
is bound to protect:


BE 1t alsu known that. relying on the government
and people of the Union. the proper exerilons Will
be applied to obtain reparatlon and security.


Those, therefore, suffering wrong or threatened
with it, and those interested by sympathy ant
DrncipIe on account of the violation OF our terrtor,
and immunities, are exhorted to lorbearance ant
peace so that the preparations for preventing the re
mova Of our landmarks, and guarding the sacred
and inestmabe rights OF American citizens, ma,
not be embarrassed by any unauthorized acts.


ENUCH LINCOLN.
BY the Governor,


> AMOS NICHOLS. Secretary of State.
Council Chamber, Portland NoU. o, 1927.

full articles.headline: OFFICIAL.
full articles.article:
TO THE EDITORS OF TAE NATIONAL IETELLIGENCER.


Geniiemea: Having reported to the Secretary OF
War, some months since that the original Plocee-
dngs of the General Court Martial, which conven-
ed ut Mobile the 5lh of December 1914, could not
be found on the flies of the Offices and subsequently,
having made similar statement in reply to note
received from d. Green. Esq. of this city, which
statement has been published in a newspaper; |
have now to request tie publication of an official let
ter on the same subject, and which is addressed to
the Secretary Of War.


Very respectfully, Il. JONES.
N0p. 14ih.

this day published how finely the Palladium and
Post story is improving. 1t is gowing rapidly the
way of the E,st Room and Jackson fire side tales
